length =*{{convert|410|ft|2|in|m|2|abbr=on}} between perpendiculars *{{convert|426|ft|10|in|m|2|abbr=on}} overall | Ship beam = {{convert|54|ft|2|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship height = | Ship draught = <!--{{convert|xxx|ft|x|in|m|2}}--> | Ship depth = {{convert|27|ft|0|in|m|2|abbr=on}} | Ship decks = | Ship deck clearance = | Ship ramps = | Ship ice class = | Ship range = | Ship power = | Ship propulsion = Triple expansion steam engine | Ship speed = {{convert|11|kn|km/h}} | Ship capacity = | Ship crew = | Ship notes = | Ship complement = 36, plus 11 DEMS gunners (''Empire Dabchick'') | Ship armament = }} |} {{location map|Canada|width=304 |lat=43 |long=-58.283 |caption=Location of the sinking of ''Empire Dabchick'' off [[Canada]]. }}
'''''Empire Dabchick''''' was a {{GRT|5,995}} [[Design 1019 ship|Design 1019]] [[cargo ship]] that was built in 1919 as '''''Kisnop''''' by Atlantic Corporation, [[Portsmouth, New Hampshire]], [[United States]] for the [[United States Shipping Board]] (USSB). She was transferred to the [[United States Maritime Commission]] (USMC) in 1937. In 1940 she was transferred to the [[Ministry of War Transport]] (MoWT) and renamed ''Empire Dabchick''. She served until December 1942, when she was torpedoed and sunk by {{GS|U-183}}.
==Description== The ship was built in 1919 by Atlantic Corporation, [[Portsmouth, New Hampshire]].<ref name=Ships>{{cite book |last1= Mitchell |first1=W.H. |last2=Sawyer |first2=L.A. |year=1995 |title=The Empire Ships |page=not cited |publisher= Lloyd's of London Press Ltd |location= London, New York, Hamburg, Hong Kong |isbn=1-85044-275-4}}</ref> She was yard number 1.<ref name=History>{{cite web |url=http://www.shipbuildinghistory.com/history/shipyards/4emergencylarge/wwone/atlantic.htm|title=Atlantic Corp., Portsmouth NH |publisher=Shipbuilding History |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
The ship was {{convert|426|ft|10|in|m|2}} [[length overall|overall]],<ref name=Wrecksite>{{cite web|url=http://www.wrecksite.eu/wreck.aspx?15647 |title=SS Empire Dabchick (+1942) |publisher=Wrecksite |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> {{convert|410|ft|2|in|m|2}} long [[Length between perpendiculars|between perpendiculars]], She had a beam of {{convert|54|ft|2|in|m|2}}, with a depth of {{convert|27|ft|0|in|m|2}}<!-- and a draught of {{convert|xx|ft|x|in|m|2}}-->.<ref name=Dabchick40>{{cite web|url=http://www.plimsollshipdata.org/pdffile.php?name=40a1069.pdf |title=LLOYD'S REGISTER, STEAMERS & MOTORSHIPS |publisher=Plimsoll Ship Data |accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref> As built, she was assessed at {{GRT|6,089}},<ref name=Ships/> <!--x,xxx [[net register tonnage|NRT]]. Her [[deadweight tonnage|DWT]] was x,xxx.<ref name=xxxx/>-->
The ship was propelled by a 359 [[nominal horsepower|nhp]] [[triple expansion steam engine]], which had cylinders of {{convert|24+1/2|in|cm}}, {{convert|41+1/2|in|cm}} and {{convert|72|in|cm}} diameter by {{convert|48|in|cm}} stroke. The engine was built by Atlantic Corporation, [[Taunton, Massachusetts]].<ref name=Dabchick40/> It drove a screw propeller and could propel the ship at {{convert|11|kn|km/h}}.<ref name=Ellis>{{cite web|url=http://www.ellisisland.org/shipping/Formatship.asp?shipid=2638|title=KISNOP |publisher=Ellis Island |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
==History== ''Kisnop'' was launched in 1919, and completed in August of that year.<ref name=History/> She was built for the USSB and was transferred to the USMC in 1937. Her port of registry was [[Portsmouth, New Hampshire]].<ref name=Mariners>{{cite web |url=http://www.mariners-l.co.uk/EmpireD.html |title=EMPIRE - D |publisher=Mariners |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> On transfer to the USMC, ''Kisnop'' was laid up in reserve.<ref name=Uboat/>
On 14 November 1940, ''Kisnop'' was given to the United Kingdom, passing to the MoWT. She was renamed ''Empire Dabchick'' and placed under the management of Sir W Reardon Smith & Sons.<ref name=Uboat/> The United Kingdom Official Number 168184 and [[Code Letters]] GNSN were allocated. Her port of registry was [[London]]. She was assessed at {{GRT|5995|link=off}}, {{NRT|4,549}}.<ref name=Dabchick40/> Later that year, management was transferred to J Morrison & Son, [[Newcastle upon Tyne]].<ref name=Uboat>{{cite web |url=http://uboat.net/allies/merchants/ships/2489.html |title=Empire Dabchick |publisher=Uboat |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> ''Kisnop'' was due to join Convoy HX 116, but did not sail in that convoy,<ref name=HX116>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx116.html |title=CONVOY HX 116 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> nor in the next convoy, HX 117.<ref name=HX117>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/hx117.html |title=CONVOY HX 117 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> ''Kisnop'' sailed in Convoy SC 28, which departed from [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]] on 9 April 1941 and arrived at [[Liverpool]], [[Lancashire]], [[United Kingdom]] on 28 April. ''Kisnop'' was carrying a cargo consisting general and special cargo, [[iron]], [[steel]] and [[truck]]s. She was bound for [[Middlesbrough]], [[East Riding of Yorkshire|Yorkshire]].<ref name=SC28a>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/sc28.html |title=CONVOY SC 28 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She straggled behind the convoy on 19 April and did not rejoin,<ref name=SC28b>{{cite web |url=http://www.warsailors.com/convoys/sc28report.html |title=Convoy SC 28 - Page 2 |publisher=Warsailors |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> putting into an [[Iceland]]ic port.<ref name=SC28c>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sc/index.html?sc.php?convoy=28!~scmain |title==Convoy SC.28 |publisher=Convoy SC.28 |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
''Kisnop'' had been renamed ''Empire Dabchick'' by 16 June 1941, when she arrived at the [[River Tyne|Tyne]]. On 18 June, she joined Convoy FN 494,<ref name=Port>{{cite web |url=http://convoyweb.org.uk/ports/index.html?search.php?vessel=EMPIRE%20DABCHICK~armain |title=EMPIRE DABCHICK |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=14 May 2011}}</ref> which departed from [[Southend on Sea]], [[Essex]] that day and arrived at [[Methil]], [[Fife]] two days later.<ref name=FN494>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/fn/index.html?fn.php?convoy=0494!~fnmain |title=Convoy FN.494 = Convoy FN.94 / Phase 5 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> On 22 June, she joined Convoy EC 48,<ref name=Port/> which had departed from Southend on 20 June and arrived at the [[river Clyde|Clyde]] on 25 June.<ref name=EC48>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/ec/index.html?ec.php?convoy=48!~ecmain |title=Convoy EC.48 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> ''Empire Dabchick'' then sailed to [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], arriving on 16 August. On 13 September, she departed Philadelphia for [[Sydney, Nova Scotia|Sydney]], [[Cape Breton Island|Cape Breton]], Canada, arriving on 19 September.<ref name=Port/> She then joined Convoy SC 47, which departed on 29 September and arrived at Liverpool on 20 October. ''Empire Dabchick'' was carrying general cargo.<ref name=SC47>{{cite web|url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sc/index.html?sc.php?convoy=47!~scmain |title=Convoy SC.47 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
''Empire Dabchick'' was a member of Convoy ON 37, which departed from Liverpool on 15 November and dispersed at sea on 20 November at {{coord|59|10|N|20|0|W}}.<ref name=ON37>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=37!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.37 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She arrived at Halifax on 9 December. On 23 December, she sailed for [[New York City|New York]], [[United States]], where she arrived on 26 December. On 18 January, she departed New York for Halifax, arriving on 21 January.<ref name=Port/> She then joined Convoy SC 66, which departed on 23 January and arrived at Liverpool on 9 February. ''Empire Dabchick'' was carrying general cargo.<ref name=SC66>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sc/index.html?sc.php?convoy=66!~scmain |title=Convoy SC.66 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She left the convoy at [[Belfast Lough]] on 8 February.<ref name=Port/> On 11 February, she joined Convoy BB 136, which arrived at [[Milford Haven]], [[Pembrokeshire]] on 13 February.<ref name=BB136>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/bb/index.html?bb.php?convoy=136!~bbmain |title=convoy BB.136 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> Her destination was [[Cardiff]], [[Glamorgan]], where she arrived that day.<ref name=Port/>
''Empire Dabchick'' departed Cardiff on 1 March for Milford Haven,<ref name=Port/> from where she joined Convoy ON 72, which departed from Liverpool on 3 March and arrived at Halifax on 19 March. She was carrying a cargo of [[coal]].<ref name=ON72>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=72!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.72 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She then joined Convoy XB4, which departed Halifax on 26 March and arrived at [[Boston, Massachusetts]], United States on 29 March.<ref name=XB4>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/xb/index.html?xb.php?convoy=4!~xbmain |title=Convoy XB.4 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She left the convoy at the [[Cape Cod Canal]] on 28 March and sailed to New York, arriving on 1 April. ''Empire Dabchick'' then made a voyage to [[Baltimore, Maryland]] and back before she departed from New York on 17 April for Halifax, arriving on 20 April.<ref name=Port/> She then joined Convoy SC 81, which departed on 23 April and arrived at Liverpool on 9 May. She was carrying a cargo of steel.<ref name=SC81>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sc/index.html?sc.php?convoy=81!~scmain |title=Convoy SC.81 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
''Empire Dabchick'' was a member of Convoy ON 98, which departed from Liverpool on 26 May and arrived at Halifax on 11 June. Two days later, she departed Halifax for [[Pubnico (village), Nova Scotia|Pubnico]], Nova Scotia, arriving the next day. On 16 July, she departed Pubnico for Halifax and New York, where she arrived on 27 July. ''Empire Dabchick'' departed from New York on 22 August for [[Cape Cod Bay]], Massachusetts,<ref name=Port/> from where she joined Convoy BX 35, which had departed Boston on 26 August and arrived at Halifax on 29 August.<ref name=BX35>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/bx/index.html?bx.php?convoy=35!~bxmain |title=Convoy BX.35 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She then joined Convoy SC 98, which departed that day and arrived at Liverpool on 13 September. She was carrying general cargo.<ref name=SC98>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/sc/index.html?sc.php?convoy=98!~scmain |title=Convoy SC.98 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref>
''Empire Dabchick'' was a member of Convoy ON 136, which departed from Liverpool on 3 October and arrived at New York on 26 October. She was carrying the convoy's [[Convoy Commodore|Vice-Commodore]], but she returned to the Clyde,<ref name=ON136>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=136!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.136 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> arriving on 6 October. She left the Clyde on 11 October, joining Convoy ON 138,<ref name=Port/> which had departed from Liverpool on 11 October and arrived at New York on 3 November.<ref name=ON138>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=138!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.138 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> She again returned to the Clyde, arriving on 16 October. She departed the Clyde on what was to be her final voyage on 15 November, joining Convoy ON 146,<ref name=Port/> which had departed from Liverpool that day and arrived at New York on 8 December. ''Empire Dabchick'' straggled behind the convoy.<ref name=ON146>{{cite web |url=http://www.convoyweb.org.uk/on/index.html?onz.php?convoy=146!~onzmain |title=Convoy ON.146 |publisher=Convoyweb |accessdate=18 May 2011}}</ref> At 09:49 (German time) on 3 December 1942, she was torpedoed and sunk by {{GS|U-183||2}} some {{convert|200|nmi|km}} south east of [[Sable Island]], [[Nova Scotia]], [[Canada]] ({{Coord|43|00|N|58|17|W}}) with the loss of all 36 crew and eleven [[Defensively Equipped Merchant Ship|DEMS]] gunners.<ref name=Uboat/> Those lost on ''Empire Dabchick'' are commemorated at the [[Tower Hill Memorial]], London.<ref name=THM>{{cite web|url=http://www.benjidog.co.uk/Tower%20Hill/Ship%20Index%20A-F.html |title=Ship Index A-F |publisher=Brian Watson |accessdate=20 May 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
